The Home Secretary informed the Cabinetthat the Cotton situation had reached a stagewhen it was important that representatives of theGovernment should proceed at an early date toManchester. They would require some instructions from the Cabinet *The Cabinet agreed That the Home Secretary and thePresident of the Board of trade should proceed at an early date to Manchester to ascertain thesituation, to impress on eachsection of the Cotton industry concerned the great importanceop urgency, and to report to theCabinet. The Cabinet had before them a Reportby the Defence of India Sub-Committee of the' CP.-324 (30) )Committee of Imperial Defence/, on the measures proposed by the Government of India for dealingwith the iif ridis . The Sub-Committee agreed with the Government of India that (a) a^plainassertion of authority, and (b) material measuresto protect our territory, are required, and they considered that the construction of the proposedroads was a practical method of achieving these objects. The alternative courses of actionput forward for the Cabinet's consideration were expressed in the following terms;-(a; to summon the Afridis and inform themcategorically that we intend to build these roadsin order:-(i) to punish them for their misdeeds ofthe past six months by denying themaccess to the Khajuri plain., and thusdepriving them of their wintergrazing grounds; and(ii) To prevent any recurrence of theirmisdeeds;(b) To summon the Afridis and inform them of our intention to build the road forthwith in language equally categorical, but less likely to provoke opposition. They might, for example,be told that the roads are not intended as apunishment.for the past but a deterrent for thefuture, and that they would not be- used by us foraggressive action, unless this was demanded by their own misbehaviour. In addition, it mightbe pointed out that the roads would be to theirown economic advantage if they acquiesced in,instead of obstructing, their construction; 2, Whitehall Gardens-, S.'"'.l,October 2, 1950.(c) to summon the Afridis, and treat theconstruction of the roads as one of the subjectsfor negotiation.As regards the specific question of themaximum commitment and risk involved in the.proposed operations, the Defence of India Sub-Committee considered that this -could be assessodonly by the authorities on the spot. At thesame time they recorded the personal opinion ofSir Philip Chetwode, Commander-in-Chief in India-designate, that a temporary reverse to our armsneed, not involve any extension of the limitedobjective proposed, together with the suggestion ofthe Chief of the Air Staff that air- forces could be used to restore any situation that might result from a temporary setback of that kind.After discussion, the Cabinet - agreed (a) That the course adopted should be a modification of course (c),.namely,to summon the Afridis and to treat the construction of the roads as one of the subjects of negotiationwhich must be Insisted, upon^(b) That if the negotiations were notsuccessful, no military .action should be taken without a decisionf r om the C ab in et.
